Coming from the amazing manga that made me laugh a lot, this anime doesn't reach its full potential. 
This season wasn't going to be my favorite and was hoping that Grand Blue could save it all. However, when saw that the studio was Zero-G, I feared it to be a mediocre adaptation. 
This studio has only created several shows and it still has yet to create a good one. Grand Blue could have been the adaptation that they were looking for, but they messed up pretty bad. 
Starting with the low budget art and animation, the first episode was a letdown. In comedy, animation canbe used to emphasize hysterical moments like in Nichijou. Lacking movement would create still frames and make the scene less attractive. Separate from the comedy, Grand Blue is about diving. It has the potential to create astounding scenes of the ocean, the marine life or the island, yet it did not surprise us with any beautiful scenery. Even at the moments where the character was in awe of the ocean, the art looked plain and didn't differentiate from its norm. 


To add on, I especially do not like the white cloud effects that low-budget anime's use to reduce the amount of background shown for each shot. They could have used filtered-out photos and it would have looked better because of its detail.


Story-wise, it follows the manga well but I've noticed that Chisa, the main heroine, has a slightly different personality from the manga. The anime makes her seem interested in Iori, instead of being indifferent to everything but diving. Anyone else noticed this?




However, the original work still stands strong and people watching this anime can expect a good laugh. If anyone becomes a fan of this series, check out the manga as well. You'll fall off your chair, laughing to tears.

*spoiler free* 
I'm going to be completely honest-- there are far more reasons to dislike this show than to like it, in all honesty. But regardless, I find myself enjoying it much more than I honestly should.
Why?
Well, it's just got this strange addictive quality that keeps me coming back to it. 
To begin with, the story is pretty simple-- it's a comedic take on a college student and his party lifestyle. That's all there is to it. It's not special or even all that realistic, but it's somewhat more fresh and interested compared to the same old school anime we frequently get in this kindagenre. For that reason alone, it makes some of the 'problematic' stuff tolerable. There's the usual tsundere stuff and the romantic feelings that make no sense and the perverted crap and etc., etc., but it's just so lovable that it makes it hard to hate. 


From what I've seen so far, the art is breathtaking. All the characters and backgrounds are gorgeous, and the water is animated really, really well. It's just beautiful, enough said. 


The opening is hard to skip, and this is coming from someone who usually watches an anime opening once or twice maximum-- usually the first episode and the last episode-- I rarely ever watch them otherwise. But the music is so much fun that I listen to it every time! The background music adds to the comedy and the closing is also pretty funny and makes me want to stay and finish it instead of moving on to something else as soon as the actual episode ends. 


In my opinion, the characters aren't exactly phenomenal. The main character is the classic comedic mc... he's got nothing inherently special about him and is honestly flawed, perverted, has bad judgement, and does very, very stupid things most of the time-- but he's secretly got a hidden nice guy side that makes pretty much every chick fall in love with him. There's the classic tsundere, the classic hot girl, etc. etc. They're all very predictable but still entertaining enough to keep watching. Personally, I don't mind the harem style romances too much-- they can be pretty fun, especially since they have a lot less of the sexual assault situations that usually make up reverse harems. 


I honestly can't believe that I'm doing this, but I'm giving this anime an 8 as of now. My inner voice is outraged, but despite how predictable and problematic this anime is, I can't bring myself to not like it. In fact, I enjoy it all too much. 


I would recommend this if you: liked Baka and Test, like harems, like dumb main characters that everyone likes for some strange reason, like cute chicks crowding MCs, like college anime, like drinking/partying lifestyles


I would NOT recommend this if you: like PC anime, want something deep, were expecting something actually about diving, wanted something sports-anime style, wanted some boy/boy tension, don't like harems, don't like tsunderes, don't like the classic dumb panty dropper mc


Have a great day everyone!

I was so excited for this. I read and loved the manga. When I heard about this, I was so incredibly giddy, especially seeing it get a well known director who has worked on Gintama, and that made it clear to me this would be good.
...but it's not. It suffers a lot from a ton of pitfalls many other comedy anime have fallen into.
Story (7) - the story of Grand Blue is incredibly irrelevant to the show. It's like a lot of comedy shows, it's merely there to serve as the basis for jokes. Which is fine, we don't need some epic drama, or someinsanely serious story for a comedy. It's serviceable, non-offending. It does it's job. It can get quite a bit repetitive though, with the joke being basically


Iori and Kitahara don't wanna do a thing, usually involving alcohol -> their upperclassmen make them do the thing -> something bad happens due to the thing, usually because they're drunk


Not the worst, but it's enough to not rate the story any higher.


Art (5) - now we're getting to the first reason of why I don't like this anime that much. First part of this, the characters. The anime's character style is fine. Characters look nice, the exaggerated faces that people have aptly named Titan faces is still there, and is very well done. The character art is pretty solid, but my god, the animation. There are so many scenes in the show where it's just a still image, with the characters donning their titan faces, with nothing really happening but them talking, and some crazy graphic going on in the background. It's like the art director thought people wouldn't understand if something was a punchline unless they could make the punchline flashy, with Newgrounds level of animation. It's absolutely, and completely jarring, watching them walking and talking with decent animation, to these sudden jump cuts. 


Sound (4) - just like art, there are parts of the sound that are well done, but then completely undone by something else. The voice acting in this show is pretty good, the VAs do a good enough job with these characters. The ending song is fun, and the opening is incredibly catchy. Despite all this praise, the sound is still a 4 for me. Why? Because literally everything else about the OST is so completely basic. Almost every scene that isn't a punchline has the same dumb track that's like nothing but a flute repetitively playing the same 5 or so notes. It's so completely uninspired, and they use it so much, except for those jump cuts I said earlier. Those suddenly have this crazy, and loud electric guitar that, like the crazy jump cut graphics, seem to be there to try and emphasize the punchlines way too much, but end up being way too distracting. This along with the stillness of these punchlines make them feel like they belong in some completely unknown, 7 minute short with a $6 budget that is always at the very bottom of an anime season preview, complete with low resolution images as a poster. 


Characters (6) - they're fine, or fair according to the 6 rating here on MAL. They have their own typical archetypes, but are handled well enough that they don't seem generic. The biggest problem is the fact that these characters are completely tied to the comedy. The show bungles the comedy more often than not, and that adversely affects the characters. The lolicon otaku has jokes involving him being an otaku. When these jokes land then it's pretty easy to forgive how generic that sounds. If these jokes don't, then you just can't let it slide that easily. It's still not horrendous though. There's also a fair bit of subversion as well, which keeps the characters from being generic. The characters are serviceable.  


Enjoyment (3) - the enjoyment of this anime is based on it's comedy, and this is what hurts me the most. 


Comedic timing is something this anime bungles terribly. These punchlines are supposed to be funny when they're abrupt and sudden, yet they don't feel sudden or snappy enough to surprise us and catch us off guard, and they linger for too long. It's like a punchline that lasts for 10 seconds, even though you already got the entire gist of the punchline in 5. If the punchlines are clever enough then that amount of timing doesn't matter much, but these punchlines are not clever. 


Even just a couple of seconds can ruin a good joke. Imagine if the punchline of a joke is a character being slapped randomly, and with one of those good slaps that just sounds painful. In the right circumstance, the snappiness of the slap as a response can be funny. It won't be as funny if the character gets slapped, but the reaction face of the character being slapped lasts for 3 whole seconds. Doing that kills the abruptness of the punchline, which is something Grand Blue's comedy hinges on.


This anime is like a server, in charge bringing the food you ordered to you, except instead of bringing it to you, he brings it halfway, and you're expected to get up and go get it. It's not the absolute worst thing you'd have to do, but the fact that you have to meet him halfway already makes him worse than other potential waiters you could have gotten. You could have gone to a restaurant that instead of making you work for that product you ordered, could have just given you what you wanted. That's how I feel about Grand Blue. It's probably not the worst anime out there when it comes to it's comedic timing, but you need to meet it halfway way too much to get any ounce of enjoyment out of it, when you can instead watch other comedy anime that don't have these glaring issues. 


Keep it on your plan to watch list, and watch it if you absolutely have no comedy anime to watch, and are desperate for some more. If not, take a pass on this. There are better, more competently directed comedy out there

I want to preface this review by saying that I have always seen Grand Blue and how it was very high in ratings as a manga but never actually came around to read it. Thus I had no previous interactions with this IP.
Throughout the years and actual solid weeks of browsing MAL, I have come to the point where I can generally guess what the highest rated anime and manga are. People similar to me should have at least heard of the manga named Grand Blue.
The anime hasn't been out long but I wanted to say that I was pleasantly surprised by the certain vibeof the anime. The art and sound could be better, the characters are quite 2 dimensional and I feel as if the story won't really progress much but I don't think the goal of Grand Blue is to tell a revolutionary story. I think the goal of the anime is to deliver a pleasant experience through the scope of an esoteric view. So far the anime has made me laugh and enjoy the experience and every week I end up excited to watch another episode of this joyful anime. Would recommend to people who enjoy more easy to follow anime.

Grand Blue is a Zero-G comedic anime from last year. I can't speak to the quality of their work in general since I only found thirteen titles listed for them and haven't seen any of them. It's based off of a manga by Inoue Kenji. Well, I like a lot of slice of life comedies so this may be relevant to my interests. Let's take a look. 
Story:
Our protagonist is Kitahara Iori. A young man who moves into his Uncle's place while attending college. Once there, he's immediately marked by the diving club, which is made up largely of drunken morons who can't keep their clothes on.They coerce him into joining, sensing a kindred spirit. The series basically covers Iori's exploits and club activities. 


Let's start with the massive, gaping issue with the series. It isn't funny. For the vast majority of it, we just watch these drunken idiots act like drunken idiots. It's like watching that group you always avoided at University very closely and that's just annoying. There's a reason you avoid the intellectual shrimps who just want to party in a loud, obnoxious fashion. Another thing the series seems to find absolutely hilarious is giving the characters stupid looking, exaggerated features. Which kind of contributes to the generally annoying atmosphere. Then we have the humour that centers around Nanaka wanting to sex up her sister. It's like the worst part of Yuru Yuri, except the rest of the humour is on par with it. 


Actually, any time this series touches on the idea of romance it's horrible in some way. Whether it's Iori getting caught being pervy towards one of his cousins, the aforementioned sister complex, the group of incels or the bisexual fan-service girl. 


Characters:


Another big problem with the series as a whole is that the characters are all horrible. You pretty much hate 95% of them within minutes of them showing up and they don't even have the defence of being well written characters. They're very shallow. Unfortunately, they're shallow in a way that makes them incredibly unbearable. 


Now, I'm not saying you need characters who are amicable for a comedy to work. The BBC's Black Adder serves as proof positive that you can have characters who are terrible people in a comedy and make it work really well. But that series has the benefit of clever writing and the writers made the titular character a charming rogue in every series save one. That factor, coupled with the cunning behind his actions does make him both interesting and funny. This series doesn't have any cleverness or charm to speak of. Which just makes the awful characters a slog to deal with. 


Art:


This is the one element where I can give the series some credit. The underwater scenes where we don't have insipid dialogue, shite facial expressions or any garbage character interactions to deal with can look very nice. If this series were just the seven or eight minutes of underwater scenery, I could enjoy it somewhat. 


Of course, it does have issues with really stupid looking facial expressions popping up constantly and the characters randomly taking off their clothes because Inoue apparently finds nudity to be the funniest thing of all time. 


Sound:


While Grand Blue does have some talented voice actors, it's also one of those series where they aren't allowed to have good performances. The dialogue is so over-exaggerated and the characters are so devoid of anything resembling complexity that it becomes nearly as annoying to listen to as it is to watch. The music is, at least, only sub-par. 


Ho-yay:


We have Nanaka with her romantic feelings towards her own sister. We also have Azusa, who is openly bisexual. The series also loves to make jokes in poor taste about people mistaking Iori for having romantic feelings towards his otaku friend. 


Areas of Improvement:


Having clever jokes instead of loud, obnoxious unfunny ones. 

There is literally no benefit to the nudity, just have your characters keep their clothes on. 

Just say no to the incest. At best, it's cringey and mildly unpleasant. At worst, it's fecking terrible. 


Final Thoughts:


This is easily among the worst comedies I've ever seen. It tries to force humour out of being loud and obnoxious but, ultimately, all that does is make it loud and obnoxious. You hate the characters pretty much within minutes of them showing up. The actors are wasted since you could just replace their lines with a crying baby and it would only be mildly more annoying. Ultimately, it's just an unpleasant, horribly written and devoid of humour work. I'm giving it a 2/10 and it only gets that high of a score because of the nice underwater scenery. If you really find drunken idiots charming, it may be the series for you. Otherwise, I'd suggest staying away from it.

Grand Blue is an anime about nude dudes drinking booze. 
.
.
.
Oh yeah, and there’s some diving and other stuff too…yep.
So right after this anime finished airing, I decided to start binge watching it because I had nothing more productive to do with my life, and I fully expected to get bored and move on to something else after a few episodes. But I didn’t. I just couldn’t stop watching it. And a few hours later, I found myself having completed the anime with a big, stupid grin plastered across my face. And there’s one major reason for this.
Grand Blue made me laugh my ass off.It’s as simple as that. Now let’s DIVE into why (Don’t worry, there are more cringy diving related puns to come).


On the SURFACE, this doesn’t even look like an anime that I would enjoy at all. I only started watching it because of the high score the manga has. I personally find watching animated shows about athletic events (like diving) to be boring. I prefer an anime to have a story with creativity and DEPTH that actually goes somewhere. And above all else, I’d like to avoid having a bunch of naked men frolic drunkenly across my screen. Yeah, that’s just not my thing. Grand Blue has all of these undesirable factors, yet I actually ended up not giving a crap, because the show was still able to be incredibly enjoyable and funny even with, and in some ways thanks to, all of these elements. And you know what? I have to give it props for getting me to like it so much.


So let’s DIVE straight to the point. Every single episode is hilarious. I can’t stress enough how important this is considering how hard it is for me to find comedy anime that have this effect on me. And the best part is that it never gets old. Yes, a lot of the gags, primarily the men getting naked and then getting drunk, are used in every episode, but for me, they retained their charm throughout. And there was always some new comedic element that happened in every episode which kept the comedy fresh and fun. One minute the characters would be playing a hilarious game of tennis, and the next they’d be failing to be bar tenders at a bar where the manager thinks they’re gay. No matter what the situation, I found myself constantly laughing. And despite how basic this sounds, good comedy can really go a long way in making a show good. Especially when it’s, you know, actually supposed to be a comedy anime. Of course, what really kept it all together was the cast.


Unlike the ocean that they dive in, these characters aren’t that DEEP. But it’s been scientifically proven that you don’t actually need a tragic backstory and depression to be a good character. Just check the study done by The Institute of Weebology. It shows some really revealing stuff. Anyway, Iori, the protagonist, is a really fun character. I knew I would like him right away when he first opened the door to the diving shop in the beginning of episode one. He may be an idiot at times, but he’s just, well, funny. Whether he’s getting drunk, getting naked, being a pervert, arguing with Kouhei, or anything else, it was just a joy to watch him. 


The other characters also all add their own charm to the show. Chisa’s somewhat of a tsundere who has trouble expressing her feelings, but is super adorable when she does. Yeah, I can totally understand why Iori’s friends were super jealous over him living with Chisa. Kouhei is an otaku who has some of the most hilarious moments in the anime, and his chemistry with Iori is amazing. Aina actually got a bit of character development, which was honestly refreshing to see. Azusa is a bi girl who likes drinking and doesn’t mind getting undressed in front of dudes. Yeah, she seems like a fun person to be around. Nanaka has a little sister fetish, and the big upperclassmen dudes Shinji and Ryuujirou love to get naked. And what do they all have in common? 


A love for beer- er, I mean, a love for diving…because this is a diving anime…Though in all seriousness, when the anime actually does get to diving, it does a great job in describing everything that goes into the activity. 


Well, that’s basically it. I know this review didn’t really get into any specifics, but I don’t think a detailed analysis of this anime is really necessary. The DIVING force of this anime truly is it’s masterful usage of comedic elements. Of course, comedy is subjective, and if the comedy of Grand Blue isn’t your style, then you probably won’t like it. But remember, when it comes to me, I didn’t think this anime would be for me at all. 


But it was still able to win me over in the end.

Sometimes there comes a show that so excellently and eloquently subverts the tropes of an entire genre of anime, and does so in a mere 5 episodes. Yes, chaps we're talking about grand blue. The anime centred around a bunch of drunk bozos chronicling their escapades in trying to get into their cousin's trousers. Grand blue is at heart a comedy anime wrapped up in a slice of life setting but it is so much more than that. Grand blue, as I alluded to earlier actively makes fun of the genre it comes from. Poking fun at Otakus, waifus, husbandos and the tiresome theme ofdistasteful incest in anime. Right from the beginning, the show makes it clear to us that the setting is comical, by juxtaposing our protagonist's dreams of women filled college life, with a large man's bare penis. This makes it clear to us, the viewer that this anime is not going to be what we dreamed of, and it is this expression of our own thought process through the characters that make this anime so brilliant. From layering jokes slowly to the sky as the viewer and the main character both begin to piece what is happening before our eyes together, to the silly nonsensical reactions of our dramatic cast of characters, they are made from the ground up to replicate the viewer's internal thoughts as their tropes are shattered before them in a hilarious inferno of comedy. As the show has not yet concluded I cannot fully rate it upon all of its merits so, as the series stands I will give it a placeholder 6/10 as there is no ending and admittedly a lack of structure to the story.

Grand Blue - looking for a sport genre anime, it was no coincidence that I came across this anime that explicitly mentions one of the most beautiful hobbies and sports as part of the story line, namely diving. Since I had not read the manga yet, I did not know what to expect. It is not a good sign if the Kanji are not at the beginning of the review, if you like the anime and hope to find an echo chamber you will be as disappointed, as I am by this anime.
Story: only a tool, no depth, a pretext or an excuse to stringcomedy elements together (3/10)

To study mechanical engineering at the University of Izu, Kitahara Iori returns to a coastal town in Shizuoka Prefecture after 10 years.  His uncle runs a dive shop where Iori wants to stay. But don't expect a serious show about diving! 


*The description of the characters may include spoilers, so first watch the anime.*


Characters: clichéd as it couldn't be worse (4/10)

In fact, it's hard to spoil anything by describing the characters, as they are so stereotypical that you've already seen them in a lot of anime and, unfortunately, even better.

Kitahara Iori:

The protagonist of the series, a newcomer who can not swim and is afraid of water. He is admitted to the diving club "Peak a Boo" (PAB) against his will. This could be a great story part as the other members of the club try to eliminate his fear of the sea. In most cases, however, it ends with a pointless comedy of booze party and nudity. A rather unsympathetic and weak MC, shortly before the end of the series, there is something like a character development, but too late to perceive it as an attenuation.

Kotegawa, Chisa :

Chisa is the same age as Iori and has known him since childhood. She is a down-to-earth and conscientious person, to whom the hobby fits well. The fact that she always looks at Iori with a little contempt when he gets completely drunk again, is a good expression for the fact that diving is a marvelous, but also very dangerous hobby, which can only be enjoy if you can rely on your dive partner. This is indispensable in dangerous situations. Admirable, that she gave him a piece of her mind about it. May the fun society see her as a party pooper with an average appearance, but that makes her the most tangible and realistic of the entire clique.

Nanaka Kotegawa:

She is the older sister of Chisa, a very good diver and chief instructor during the dives. She is a very pretty woman and with a consistently friendly nature, she is a real dream girl. Too bad that she has only eyes for her little sister and so strong that it is a real siscon. This is also used for the comedy, but so exaggerated that it is rather unpleasant.

Kouhei Imamura:

He acts as a rival character to Iori. He looks good, but has the completely unrealistic notions of a hardcore Otaku and that's why, despite his good looks, he can not find a girlfriend among his fellow students. His obsessive devotion to a well-known voice actress changes slightly when he meets Chisa. His fetish is also used several times for comedy but the only remarkable scene is, when the girls are buy diving utilities and try on some special diving suits that look like from the anime Neon Genesis Evangelion (the white = Rei Ayanami; the red = Asuka Langley Soryu). To be honest, I could even understand him. *cheeky grin*

Ryuujirou Kotobuki & Shinji Tokita 

They are both final year`s students and members of the PAB. They are the senpai for the newcomers, so for Iori and Kouhei. Unfortunately, the seriousness rarely comes into play, rather the two encourage drinking bouts. The two students are very different in appearance, Tokita is dark-haired and very muscular and Kotobuki is blond, also muscular, but with a different defined muscle structure. But in the way they behave or better, misbehave, they are birds of a feather. In their defense,  it should be added that the little they teach about diving is correct.

Azusa Hamaoka:

She is also a senior student, but at a women's university. She is also a member of the PAB and is not far behind Shinji and Ryuujirou in terms of drinking. She is very sexy and knows how to use it. On the other hand, she has a lascivious and playful but very feminine style, since she is also honest and direct, she often knocks her interlocutor out of his stride. To top it all off, she is bisexual and finds both Shinji and Nanaka attractive.


*spoiler alert end *


Visuals: medium quality, inspired moments aren`t well presented enough (4/10)

The art is only slightly above the average and rather of medium quality. The saddest thing is that the actually very beautiful underwater world was presented with only a little more effort. Although these scenes are probably among the best of the anime, this is unfortunately no compliment. The 

The animation is sufficient to convey the emotions and scenes correctly, but it is no more than standard. On the other hand, the comic-art-style, though popular and similarly presented by the manga, is aggressive and perceived quickly as exaggerated in the anime. The first few times it's fun, but the constant repetition throughout the whole anime, in the same aggressive and harsh way, makes it just seem repulsive at the end. Usually this style fits the genre but unfortunately it's over the top here.


Sounds: BGM generic, OP nice (5/10)

The BGM is not bad, the only aspect that shows at least some effort to do something good. I didn't perceive the BGM to be extraordinary, but also not disturbing or inappropriate.

The 1. OP "Grand Blue" by Shōnan no Kaze is cheerful and has what it takes to be a catchy tune.

The 1. ED, I don't like the song "Konpeki no al Fine" by Izu no Kaze, but both the vocals and the animation make it clear what you can expect in the next episode. If you find the ED funny, you can continue with the next episode.

The 2. ED, „Konpeki no Al Fine: Mizuki Kaya by Mizuki Nana is the same title as the first ED and was only used for episode 11. As last ED was again, the first OP "Grand Blue" by Shōnan no Kaze "used.

The voice actors were not really bad, but not very good either. Nevertheless, I particularly liked the following voices: Tokita, Shinji spoken by Yasumoto, Hiroki; Kotegawa, Chisa spoken by Anzai, Chika as well as Hamaoka, Azusa spoken by Yukinari, Toa. Yukinari-san, in the voice role, has adopted a gentle, feminine note that goes very well with the cheeky, sexy Azusa. 

The sound effects were overall fitting, the dialogue directing had even some very clever ideas that were unfortunately lost in the nonsense comedy.


Meanwhile I have read a few chapters, the manga is more bearable, but not really better. Even if you're not interested in the sport itself and love comedy, I can not recommend this show because it is predictable, rough, loud and aggressively stupid.The comedy is a guilty pleasure that destroys even the few inspired moments of the shows. All in all, unfortunately, I have to say it was not worth it.



Thanks for reading.

I wasn't planning on watching this, but my friend who reads and enjoys the manga urged me to since the main character is "an engineering student who can't swim but likes the ocean" like me. I thought I'd give it a go since I like comedy and also because the manga is so popular. 
This will be a pretty short review.
Humor is subjective but honestly, most of the humor in every single episode boils down to the same three things:
- Kohei and Iori refuse to drink and/or get naked and then 5 minutes later they're doing exactly that.
- Iori and his other virgin friends beingjealous of any other guy who has a gf\n
- Something going on between Chisa and Iori.\n\n
Additional notes:\n
- Not sure about what engineering is like in Japan but like, what kind of engineering student has that much time to waste doing... whatever it is Iori's doing half the time?\n
- Most of the female characters are unbearably boring except Azusa who I DO actually like. She's the real MVP for trying to get Iori and Kohei together just because Iori lied to her and told her that he likes him lol.\n
- My rating is biased I guess because of the fact that I don't really like harem anime.

Let this open the floodgates to more college and drinking oriented anime.
Grand Blue is an adaptation of the critically acclaimed manga of the same name serialized in the good! Afternoon magazine. It tells a tale about a young "20-year old" college student looking forward to a fresh start after enduring three years at an all boys high school. Little does he know that everything that can go wrong in his college life, will go wrong.
Since I'm writing this review as a manga enthusiast, the jokes didn't hit me as hard as it could have since I'm technically experiencing them for a second time. But evenso, many of the scenes were still hilarious and wonderfully directed to emphasize the humor captured in the manga. I didn't expect any less from Shinji Takamatsu, an experienced director that has done Danshi Koukousei no Nichijou and Gintama. Many pages that I've re-read over and over again still got me laughing because of how well done the comedy was. I'm sure that, if I didn't read the manga beforehand, I would've rated this show a 10/10 like I did with the manga. 


Before reading Grand Blue, my experiences with anime comedies were mainly derived from romantic comedy shenanigans that heavily abuse the typical anime tropes you pick up quickly when you first get into this medium. Not to say that I don't love this type of humor because I do, but there were very few comedies that I've experienced that tries to deviate from your typical fanservicey romantic comedy type jokes such as Nichijou and Hataraku Maou-sama!


Grand Blue is the type of comedy that takes another step forwards towards expanding the boundaries to what could be considered a successful comedy. It was very risky creating a comedy targeted towards young adult men that was focused towards heavy drinking and positive college experiences, a characteristic that tends to be less popular among the otaku community. But even so, Kenji Inoue decided to say "Fuck it, I'm going to write a manga that parodies frat culture and I don't care if it's not going to be popular among the magazine's audience". And boy did that pay off.


However, the courage to take these such risks itself isn't what makes comedy good. No, the setting only attracts viewers that don't have previous knowledge of the franchise. The reason why Grand Blue is phenomenal is how easy it is to develop emotional attachments to the characters even though it's not supposed to be taken seriously.


The characters are by far, the best part of Grand Blue. There is not a single character that I don't like in the show. Every character feels like it has a purpose, and nothing feels like it's left out. If comedy could be critiqued with plot holes, then you'll never find a single plot hole in Grand Blue.


The gags are wonderfully well relatable settings that exaggerate the possibility of things going wrong. Every terrible experience, every hard lesson that you may have learned in college will make you laugh it all off once you view these characters' experiences. Everything in the show goes so wrong that you'll start to understand "Hey, maybe getting the short end of the stick is what makes so life exciting and the climb more worthwhile". It's the heartwarming down-to-earth comedy that makes it so relatable.


Every gag in the story is never wasted. Every misunderstanding in the story always carries over. Characters are all so easily recognizable by their personalities that you know what is going to happen. A lot of people say that if the comedy is predictable, then it's mediocre. But I feel like if the characters are so distinguishable enough that you can predict what will happen based on they previous experiences and personalities, then it becomes the best kind of predictable.


I can understand why not everybody will enjoy the humor in this show, however. Comedy is subjective, and in my experience, comedy isn't funny if I cannot relate to the events and experiences portrayed in the show. If you genuinely don't like it because you detest the vibes that the events give you, then by all means don't continue to watch it. If Grand Blue doesn't capture your heart in the first few episodes, then please just drop it because you won't enjoy the rest of it. You will know if you love this show right from the get-go.


The only reason why I can't give this show a perfect score is because Zero-G has room for improvement and although it looks solid, I believe Grand Blue is a comedy that deserves production values on the scale that studios like Kyoto Animation have. But for now, I can settle with just having an anime alone as again, Takamastu still did an incredible job with bringing a manga comedy to life.

Sorry Grand Blue, you took 2nd place (behind Asobi Asobase) for comedy this season, but you're still a great show to watch, bar none!
Grand Blue wasn't one of the shows I'm intending to watch from the get-go, but its comedy presents the significant change and pace of time with "How I Live My College Life". Add to that the insane number of recommendations that the manga counterpart was more than amazing, I just couldn't resist the anime adaptation by Zero-G, and it definitely doesn't quiver at its shots and the single most-handedly important aspect: To not take itself too seriously. Oh, and the aforementioned warningbefore every episode, because this is a drinking anime too.


The setting for Grand Blue is pretty much the same format as how Amanchu! has had going for it: the (scuba) diving aspect, with how Gintama has had their comedic episodic formats before. Mesh both series together, and you get the college life humour-esque of a funny bones series. But if you start to think that Grand Blue is all about diving, you're in for a hard-pressed fall, because it ain't so in the first place!


Imagine this: You are starting a new life, you want to learn a new passion, but when you get there, everything is nuts and bolts jokerish-status significant of a rowdy circus, you immediately back out! But, something about it grows on you and you start to love it despite the insane gags that are shoved right up your A-hole. Some mature and WTF-moment comedy ensues, and once you know it, you're already in for the ride. How amazing is that!?


The characters are what gives life to mindless and endless amount of idiosyncrasies of many screws that are funnily screwed loose. The veterans Shinji, Ryuujirou, Azuna and Nanaka, all of them have quite the expertise on scuba diving...and not to mention, their own "fragrant" charm, with the men running around and doing things naked (oh God that was so funny) and the sexy charm of the ladies, with their ever so tempting bodies that set the main male MCs (especially Iori) heart ablaze.


And in comes the juniors: Iori, Kouhei, Aina and Chisa (reason on that in a while). Iori and Kouhei are truly the definition of yaoi stuff, just due to how much as they care for each other, they BURN and get rekt together (with their friendzoned friends of single-getting-hitched relationships) in the bestest fashion possible, always trying to find a way out when that way didn't promise much for them, but at least you guys tried (I like that!). Aina, or Cakey, as per the incredibly cheap but creepy-as-molasses makeup turn out to be, joins the Grand Blue club to witness her love blossom for Iori, and in the meantime, the seniors and both men spoil her imaginary prowess with tainted oblique circles of their private parts (kinda wished that censorship didn't exist!). Chisa, like veteran, like junior. Her diving skills no one can match, but her heart is like a fleeting moment (always for Iori, and she DID stole his limelight moment). An unfortunate character who has to content with not only being the only girl in the all-guys course (whatever it is), but her tsundere-ness is the weak link as these emotions go unanswered (but we all know HAHA).


For such an awesome manga adaptation, Zero-G really dinged it hands down while playing its hands cleverly. The only outlier would be the areas that doesn't look or feel polished, such as the diving scenes, but hey, I can live with it as the comedic SoL moments is what really breathes life and the art and animation in all its glory is not outcasted nor disappointing here. The weird moments where guys go naked, to the one-to-one perfection of the face expressions of hurt, S&M aesthetics and the like that always breaks the laughter puns, piece by piece. Especially the close-up scenes of fanservice galore *hehe...*


The music is IMO what represents the series well, going into it for the very first time didn't feel like a chore in comparison as opposed to just subverting the show from the get go. The OP which coincidentally share the same name as said title, was great to the point where the introduction felt very welcoming and representing the summer season (hey, it's Summer too!). If you thought that you were done from the comedic moments in the episodes, the ED pulls out a hearthstone as an object of affinity and insanity. Overall, a great choice of music that's pure enjoyment.


It's hard to believe that Grand Blue was lead by one person alone: well-famed director Shinji Takamatsu, who is the creator of awesome comedy series such as the No. 1 comedy fan-favourite Gintama and one of my favourite school rom-coms, School Rumble. Personally, he lead as overall director, sound director and scriptwriter, and his talents are truly unmatched. Yes, the manga by Kenji Inoue (Baka to Test) is splendid, but Takamatsu's Gintama magic hand just adds onto the overall well-positive experience.


Out of all the comedy we could have this season (Chio-chan, Asobi Asobase and this series), Grand Blue will be the one that most can recognize and relate to, due to the realism that you're basically living what is known as the best moment of your life: College. Where you can do stuff that not even your parents can oppose you to doing, so as long as it's beneficial to your "healthy and fun" being. Overall I can recommend Grand Blue to everyone despite the demographic difference, because it either brings you back or forward (from where you are now) to how your college life is or will be: Purely all for fun.

Going to be honest... this show is my largest disappointment of the Summer 2018 season. Not because it's awful, but because the manga was so much better. This anime is fun, lively, and looks reasonably pretty, but unfortunately, it does something completely inferior to the source material, the timing of it's jokes.
The structure of a manga just lends itself better to the style of comedy than the anime. The pacing is just better and allows for the jokes to land more quickly and not painfully drag out. While this anime keeps the same jokes with relatively one-to-one recreations, this direct adaption approach didn't keep manyof them well structured. A lot of them still work, just not as well.


Along with this, the art may look reasonably good, however, the roughness and the nature of panels support the incredible expressions so much better. Many of the expressions are still good, but they lack the sharpness and extreme levels of the original.


All out, what makes Grand Blue a disappointment in my eyes, is the fact that it doesn't hold up to the source material. My philosophy is that if a piece of media isn't improved through adaption, it shouldn't be adapted at all.

Grand Blue: the Strip Rock-Paper-Scissors and Alcoholism show.
It is a show about diving, in the same way School Days is a romance. The diving element takes second place to the show’s main genres: slice of life and comedy. Which, in itself, isn’t necessarily a bad thing. 
Slice of life shows can be great. They can be relaxing, heart-warming, and funny. They can make you laugh or cry. Or, they can make you cringe.
This show falls most definitely into the latter category. And a perfect example of this lies in its characters, an aspect that normally makes or breaks slice-of-life shows. 
First off: Two bodybuilder lookalikeswho do very little in the show besides encourage the MCs to drink themselves silly, get naked at every opportunity, and all around just be negative influences. I think they’re meant to be ‘manly’ characters but the only – and I mean the only time we ever see them getting serious is when they talk about diving. The rest of the time they consume massive quantities of mixed drinks (as well as encouraging/forcing others to do the same) and show very little respect for anyone. They think nothing of humiliating someone if it’s to raise money for their precious diving club (which must have been shown at least ONCE in the anime by now).


I’m trying to think of more to say about them and I can’t. They’re good at tennis? They’re essentially the musclebound, brain-dead stereotypical college guys we’re all embarrassed to be around unless we’re wasted. Maybe some people watching this will be reminded (fondly, or not so fondly) of their own college/uni days. Either way, although I found watching them enjoyable, it was only because sometimes I just need to watch something ridiculously cringey. 


Take away majority of the nudity, decrease the drinking (yes, there still needs to be drinking but not 3 drinking sessions per ep), and add a few more scenes where they show off their diving expertise. Then these two would have actually gone from being comic characters to being decent, slightly fleshed-out characters.


Iori, the MC…where do I begin? 

Spineless? He’ll back down when confronted with anyone angry but it’s not quite what I’m looking for. Reckless? He’s definitely that but without the confidence needed to be properly reckless. Pathetic? Well, he grovels on the floor often enough, gives in when confronted with any sort of peer pressure, and frequently embarrasses himself by making offensive remarks to others.  


The only time he’s ‘confident’ is when he’s been egged on by his ‘friends’, or when making objectifying comments to his cousin (who, by the way, he seems to fancy) - and that might just be mistaking idiocy for confidence. 


The sad part is that when he’s by himself he actually seems to be quite a decent human being. He’s the type of person that is ruined by bad friends, and his ruin is shown clearly in the anime. He literally goes from being the new guy to being the creepy laughingstock of the university in one episode, after his ‘friends’ deliver him to the entrance passed out drunk and wearing nothing but a pair of boxers.


The only real thing, the only thing that makes him partway relatable is his struggle when it comes to swimming and diving. He starts off by being afraid of the water, but actually faces his fears and becomes a better person for it. 


This is in no small part due to Nanaka and Chisa, two of the female leads of the show. Nanaka can be disposed of easily as she is completely one-dimensional from the beginning. Iori’s sweet, kind cousin who’s also in love with her sister (to the extent of acting like a yandere over her). She appears randomly, makes some nice comments, helps people out with things and then disappears again. Exploring her background a little, or even her relationship with her sister would have helped give her more depth, but no. Maybe next season.


Chisa is a far more interesting character. She’s just as kind in her own way, but will not suffer fools gladly. At some points she feels like the only sane character in the series. She despises some of the guys’ more vulgar actions, and has no patience for Iori’s ill-timed and ill-humoured comments. But somehow, even miraculously, she realises that he’s not intrinsically a bad person. Immature yes, but a person with his own struggles and fears. She helps him a lot, both when he’s looking and when he isn’t. Plus, she’s adorable.


Iori’s best friend is…pitiful. Yep, that’s probably the best way to describe him. He’s almost exactly a carbon copy of Iori but with an added anime obsession. Perhaps he does have slightly more sense, but no matter how much he protests he always ends up joining in with Iori’s idiotic schemes and mistakes. The two of them argue frequently, which is fun to watch initially, but soon becomes as boring as it is repetitive. He doesn’t seem to have any character development either, besides learning how to drink an entire bucket of vodka in one. It’s development…of a sort.


Aina, or ‘cakey’ is the unusual one of the cast, and actually fairly likeable. She has some character development too, which I’m not going to go into as that would spoil at least one ep. I will say though, the eps with her in were the ones I enjoyed the most. Plus, she’s kind of relatable, in that ‘weird but not downright loony’ way. Someone needs to give her a make-up tutorial though.


Purple haired girl is a fun character to watch. There has to be at least one girl who’s as crazy as all the boys, right? To prove that strong, independent, alcoholic women with no inhibitions do exist. Oh, and she’s loud. Raucous laughter echoes wherever she goes. But despite all that, she’s a kind, loyal friend, the type you don’t want to hang with all the time but you’re glad for when push comes to shove, because you know she’s got your back. You can also tell her all the stuff you can’t share with anyone else. And she won’t spill it (unless it’s for a laugh, then you’re on your own). She brings a lot of life to the cast (which is basically a good thing), and does provide the setup for a fair few awkward situations. 


So there you have the cast. There’s not much to say about the rest. 


Art? I’m no judge. Lots of incredibly creepy facial expressions though – they border on caricatures a lot of the time. 


Music? I really enjoyed the music, and found myself singing along to the op more than once. Thumbs up for that. “Be passionate, my friends,” and all.


Plot? See above. Oh and there’s a bit of diving thrown in.


Overall: Now, of course lots of people will enjoy this show. I did myself, in parts. But will anyone enjoy it because it’s a deep meaningful show? Of course not. It’s the type of show people come to laugh at. It’s the type of immature humour that can be completely hit or miss. 


It is not a good show. But it’s a funny show, in its own way. 


As I mentioned earlier, sometimes you just need to watch something ridiculous for the fun of it. If brainless fun, with a high dose of cringe, is what you’re looking for, you’ll enjoy this one.

I started watching this because I watched Prison School and I heard this had the same kind of humour. After watching it I can say that it's funny but not as funny as Prison School. The show has a very simple story, about a young man who wants to have the perfect college life, but gets into some weird shit. The art is amazing IMO, and the ocean and beaches and stuff look beautiful. The sound is just normal sound, but I really like the intro song. The characters are well thought out. The enjoyment is pretty good, but sometimes it does get a littlebit boring. Overall it's a very cute anime and it's nice to just watch and chill. I hope for a second season.

When I decided to watch this anime I did not read the plot. Based on the picture I thought it would be a typical school romance taking place in a coastal city along with the usual slapstick comedy and other cliches that we have been used to. But I never ever expected this to be one of the funniest comedies I have watched in a long time.
The characters are hilarious, the comedy is top-notch and it is such an enjoyable watch that will give you a great time and summer vibes! All the characters are likeable and have their own "intricacies" and peculiarities, which enhancesthe comedy part even more!


The plot is nothing special and does not really lead anywhere. It is mostly supportive and acts as a foothold for the comedy, as a channel through which the comedy flows. However, it is presented in such an amusing way that will keep you entertained throughout the duration of the series. The animation is visually pleasing. The music is good and enhances the intensity of the comedy scenes. The opening song is very memorable and catchy and I ended up never skipping it whenever I was starting a new episode. 


Overall, a very relaxing story that will give you a great time watching it, big laughs and it is very possible that you might relate to it if you like drinking parties! It will also "broaden your perspective" by introducing alternative ways that a simple game like Rock, Scissors and Paper can be played... ...you will understand very soon what I mean after you start watching it...!!!


A great comedy and a must see!

Grand Blue
I expect so much as an anime watcher from this show, since i always hype about anime that has no school story, unviersity is a complete difference experience than school, that's why i always hype or looking forward to watch anime that has this kind of story ever since i watched genshiken (a bit) and golden time.
But, as i watched the first episode i kinda feel something is wrong with this. The art is really entertaining (i really like comedy with OVERDETAILED face, it makes the comedy even good) thats the good part, but not all of it is that good. For me thestory is kinda bland. It confuse me on what part the story want to focus to, is it the comedy? the club? the relationship? idk, i know the story is not all, but because the story is not all, at least focus on something. Well at least the comedy is good i almost always laugh on every episode because of it. And watching iori and kouhei bonding is fun too, but i still can't accept it end just like that, it just feels too hanging and bland.


I know that the point of this anime is showing a heavy comedy while showing us how beautiful is our world (sea) is. But IMO there are two ways to do a heavy comedy.

One is do the heavy comedy with light story,

and the other one is do the heavy comedy along with the heavy story.


I feel that Grand Blue doesn't choose either of them, making it so unbalanced. The gap between the story and the comedy is big, making it kinda feels weird when the anime actually tells what's the story about.


After watching it, all i can say is not every anime is for everyone.

Its an anime for you that searching anime with heavy comedy and light story.

Okay! So, I know we guys have a lot of preferences when it comes to anime some of us like Harem, Romace, Drama, Action, Horror, Psychological etc., And sometimes Comedy. We have our own opinion on the matter, depending on how an Anime connect to us. So here is my un-biased opinion or review on this one because i am an anime lover no matter the genre is.
Honestly before i began the series i had my doubts, I was thinking weither this anime be any good, so i didn't get my hopes up on this one, but, to my surprise after watching the first epi got hooked!


Story: Its about the life of a freshman going to college for the 1st time and he is really excited, just like me back then, to make it more exciting he's going to school far away from home, whoooo sounds more fun! You can do everything you want, so he started living with his uncle along with some weird people, or should i say "Bad Influences?" 😂 Along with his 2 beautiful fanservice female cousins (its moderate so we good). He was forced to join their club "Diving Peek a Boo Club" and turns out his unlce's house is where the club members meet, because, its a Rental Diving Store called the Grand Blue (yeah it's the name of the anime) to make the long story short, he got influenced met some odd new people along the way, and he got wasted till the end 😂. 


The story has no serious plot more like a Sitcom (forgot the other term, Slice of life?) type of anime. The story talks about college life, we all experienced it in some way, or some weird and funny way, so this anime has a bit of connection to me personally, made me think back while i was in college and how crazy we are back then, you know parties and stuff, its a part of life or should i say the part where you lose your virginity 😂. Hey no regrets! 😂 You made a irreversible decision 😂. So that's the gist of it. For me it was good and refreshing i like it! It's crazy and fun to watch. 8/10


Art: hmmmm.. art is in moderate level, I noticed they focused more in making the characters to look more appealing. It's 8/10


Sound: feels like i'm driving a convertable feeling the ocean breeze on my cheeks while fading away on the sunset. 8/10.


Characters: They are funny all of them has some characteristics that make them cute and funny. Again there is no serious plot so there is no major character developments put it in mind that this is comedy. I laughed all the way through so. 8/10.


Enjoyment: Did I or did I not enjoy this? Well i laughed at every episode so hell yeah! I was hoping for more actually. 10/10.


Overall: it was worth the binge! I did not regret watching this, it was fun it was new, a little bit of mature! So i don't recommend this for youngsters so don't destroy your life yet! 😂 Some puns and scenes here are dangerous to your health. I would give it an 8/10. If you wanna have a blast of real comedy though, you better watch Gintama! 😂 So there it is! Sayonara!

*updated review
I score based on enjoyment, and not on "the music here was inappropriate" and "the characters weren't relatable enough". Obviously, those things do factor into enjoyment but I dont score each individual factor and bust out the calculator for an average score. Regardless, I will talk about the story art sound etc. too, however briefly.
Story-9
The story is pretty basic, which isn't a bad thing at all. Its a pretty linear and easy to follow story and it fits the premise of the Anime. As a comedy, the settings and events that take place perfectly set up the jokes and such. 
Art- 8
The art isgood, animation is a bit choppy, but the titan faces, scenery, and characters in general are well drawn. 


Sound-9

The OP and ED is great and the music doesn't feel out of place anywhere. A large variety of music and sounds too, so songs don't feel overused or repetitive. The voice actors initially seemed mediocre but they grew on me more and more as the story progressed.


Character-10

This is a purely comedy based anime, and the characters are made perfectly for it. They all have their little traits and whatnot that make them unique, although their style is pretty normal. By the end of the show, all the characters are well developed, unique, and especially lovable in their own ways. 


Enjoyment-9

Only thing that matters, obviously everything above factors into enjoyment. As a comedy, this anime meets pretty much every requirement. The only thing I do believe needs work on is the pacing in the first few episodes. I don't, however, blame them for this as the source material is so joke-packed that itd be hard for anyone to adapt (Zero-g actually does a great job adapting most of the jokes, it just feels rushed at times). The pacing definitely got better afterwards, which made it more enjoyable.  


Cool, thats about it. The overall score is the same as the Enjoyment score and I hope it gets another season, as the manga is pretty far ahead and stays consistently good. Definitely a good and worth while comedy to watch.

What is comedy to you? Is it a bunch of naked guys drinking like there's no tomorrow? Grand Blue is not your anime if that is what you're looking for. This is a show about diving.
I've never read the manga, but I'll assume it's similar and explains how diving works. With that being said, Grand Blue is great at showcasing the beautiful landscape of the beach and the ocean, the exceptional personalities of the cast, and most of all... the wonderful joy of youth. The motivating opening gives you an uplifting and summer vibe that, if you were watching it while it was airing, makesyou want to dance and enjoy the summer to its fullest extent. Honestly, watching Grand Blue during any other season just takes its charm away. It's summer. Enjoy it while watching this show.


Much of its comedy is comprised of arguments and booze, which make up a huge portion of the anime. But don't stress. Remember. This is about diving. But because Grand Blue also wants to gives us other things, the comedy is just a bonus, you know? The characters are funny. Maybe not funny to others, but I found them hilarious. In terms of entertainment, Asobi Asobase takes the cake, but when it comes to the whole vibe, Grand Blue is king. Despite the fact that it isn't actually what it's supposed to be, it's still an anime that truly fits this season. The animation is stunning. Yeah, the faces, I know, the ridiculous facial expressions. But the look of the Grand Blue shop is just... dazzling. The scenery of the ocean, the beaches, the shops, the places, it's all eye-candy for me. I loved the bright and sunny depiction of these locations.


Now back to the comedy. Not everyone likes it. Not everyone will enjoy it. I'm pretty sure most viewers have read the manga and are (probably) disappointed with what they got. As for me? I liked it. It was good. Nothing remarkable. It was just... good. I'm satisfied with what I got.

pros:
- the opening theme is an absolute bop
- quality art whether its of the underwater world or just people half naked 
- the characters all add something to the show, and i don’t think there’s any that are at all dislikable; although they are designed for comedic purposes (aka exaggerated), they still have unique traits/quirks that cause the watcher to feel more interested in them
- soundtrack works well in supporting the mood of a scene
- occasionally they do a close up of iori’s eyes and not to be a creep or anything but he’s got really pretty eyes and it makes everything worth while
cons:
- thejokes get repetitive every once in a while\n
- the slight theme of incest may put people off?

Now when it come to the sound category, the one that has the most impact here was Cakey's monologue when we see her scream, shout or rant, Iori and Kohei's monologue did add to the impact when they're duking out and it can be considered as a big plus to this anime's comedy genre, so at this point I really have no more words to say to this Outstanding anime, cu'z basically this could be considered watching something that can be the best thing that has happened to your life and damn someone if they think that this is a worst anime , when a lotta funny was in this anime,so given that I have nothing more to say, here is waht I say about this anime's ratings:

Enjoyment- Very Good 8: Totally not boring and some thing you can rewatch.


Overall- Outstanding 10: Kudos to original creator 	Inoue, Kenji and kudos to Studio Zero-G , and If this will have a 2nd season the YEAH LET THE PARTY START!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oh man, when I saw the announcement for Grand Blue, a show I'd never heard of, on Reddit, I was excited for a scuba themed anime. When I commented as such, someone replied, cryptically: "It's good, but I wouldn't say it's about diving." I had no idea what this meant, but I dove right in when I found out I was already paying for Amazon Prime and didn't even know it. SPOILER FREE though I just finished ep 3 so I don't think I could if I wanted to
Story: 7/10. Not too much of a story, just a boy heading into college with all thelofty, lusty ambitions of the classic 18 year old. There's a general flow to the eps that make logical sense as they indoctrinate Iori into the club. The comedic timing is great, and I was laughing hard at this show. Last show to make me crack up was Blend S, but this is even better. A bit too much on the fanservice, but it's more dongs than tits tbh. Besides, who needs a beach ep when the whole show is in swim suits??


Art: 10/10. Maybe it's just the current generation of anime, but I love the art here. It's crisp, and the nature visuals are striking. 


Sound: 8/10. I like the OP and ED a lot. I don't notice the rest of the OST but since it's not intrusive I find that to be a plus, given that the show is a laidback comedy and not a drama or action show.


Characters: 9/10. They're all good so far. They all have strengths and weaknesses and mesh well with each other. 


Enjoyment: 10/10. I'm not too big on comedy anime but I wanted to see this one, thinking it would be like the underwater version of Yuru Camp. I was wrong, but I'm glad I was. This show is a knee slapper. Don't listen to that spoiler-sport who gave it a 1/10. He's just a sour Sally. 


Overall: 9/10. I recommend this show for all these reasons. I'm hesitant to give it a 10 since only 5 eps are out now, but it's worth at least a look. You'll know by the first episode if you'll like it or not, so what's 20 mins of your time anyways?

I don't see what's so Grand about it.
~ Grand Blue
A comedy/slice of life anime adaptation of one of the highest rated manga on MAL. I have heard nothing but praise when it comes to the manga as everyone keeps saying how funny it is. I've heard that Grand Blue doesn't make the reader slightly chuckle. It makes them laugh out loud. I have never touched the manga, but after doing some research, I found out that its anime adaptation would air during the summer of 2018. I looked forward to it and when it finally aired, I watched it. Cool, so it was good? Sadly,no.


This is a pretty late review as quite some time has passed since then, but better late than never, I guess.


There's way too much wrong with this anime.


For starters, although I've always heard of how funny Grand Blue is, I didn't find the anime to be funny at all. It made me chuckle a couple of times and that's it. Now, I don't watch slice of life anime for the comedy. I enjoy that particular genre of anime for the characters. I don't demand slice of life/comedy anime to make me laugh myself to death. Characters that are up to my liking is all I want and that's what entertains me. So why am I talking about Grand Blue's humor if it's not what I watch slice of life anime for? That's because Grand Blue is one of the least funny comedy anime I've ever seen.

I understand that humor is entirely subjective, but the way this show does humor is just horrible.

Grand Blue's gags are predictable and repetitive. I'll describe some of their gags and jokes. There's that one gag where the male characters take off their clothes, so that they're either left with their underwear or just plain nude, and every other character who sees them gets either triggered, disgusted or surprised. That's not funny. Then there's the gag where Iori and Kouhei get tricked into getting drunk. That's also not funny. They think that by using the same unfunny gags every single episode, which become predictable, that they will eventually become funny. They never did.


Then we have the one time gags, like the one I'll be describing:

The characters are at a bar. Iori and Kouhei decide to try their hands at being bartenders.

Aina: "All right, I'll have a screwdriver!" (The name of a cocktail. Yeah, weird name.)

Iori: "A screwdriver..."

Kouhei: "I got it."

Me: Thinking. "Let me guess, they are going to put a screwdriver into her glass and offer it to her?

Iori and Kouhei: They do exactly what I thought they would.

Aina: "Hold on..." and then she starts screaming at them.

Me: Gives no reaction whatsoever.

. . . How exactly is that funny? It's predictable and just plain stupid. Predictable jokes aren't funny. And yes, I'm aware that comedies are nothing without stupid characters doing stupid things, but in order for it to work, it has to be the right kind of stupid. Grand Blue doesn't have the right kind of stupid. Most of its humor is predictable, repetitive and not funny. Grand Blue only managed to make me chuckle twice. The part where everyone screws over Iori when they tried to help Chisa win the beauty contest and the part where Iori and his friends decide to screw over one of their friends who's about to get laid. That's all.


Now I'll talk about why I like slice of life anime. The characters. Characters either make or break a good slice of life anime. Grand Blue's characters don't just break the anime. They shatter it. Halfway through the show, I genuinely started thinking to myself when exactly would Grand Blue's characters give me literally anything that would make me like them. Spoiler, they never gave me anything. Grand Blue's cast of characters is one of the worst I've ever seen.


First we have Iori, the main character. He just moved to his uncle's scuba diving shop and his life as a university freshman has begun. He gets roped into joining the diving club and takes Kouhei with him. Where did his character go wrong? Well, for starters, he had no character to begin with. You heard it right. The main character has no character. How could I possibly like him? Then we have Kouhei. He's an otaku and that's all there is to him. He and Iori have a scumbag friend relationship, but sadly, it's not any good. Both of their characters are just not interesting or relatable.


Tokita and Kotobuki are two muscular, alcohol loving idiots who rope Iori into joining their diving club. They both sucked. Both of them are a part of a repetitive unfunny nude gag and that seems to be the only reason they exist, because the show doesn't give them anything that would make the viewer like them. Also, when it comes to anything diving related, their characters perform a shocking 180 degrees and all of a sudden, they are both knowledgeable and responsible individuals. Diving can be dangerous, after all. If an old lady saw the duo when they were out diving, she would be thinking something like this: "Oh, my. These young men are so responsible and mature. If only more youngsters were like them." But if she saw how the duo behave at their drinking parties, she'd get a hearth attack out of pure shock.


Grand Blue's other characters aren't anything worthy of praise either.

Chisa Kotegawa is Iori's cousin. She hates men, mostly Iori, and loves diving. She appears to be quite cute, but has a lackluster personality. Nanaka is her older sister who loves her to the point it becomes weird and degenerate. Azusa is a bisexual airhead. Iori and Kouhei's friends are also uninteresting. All of them are simply bitter virgin friends. Everyone I just described has a lackluster personality.


Aina is the character I disliked the least. She actually manages to stand out, but that's not exactly worthy of praise, because who wouldn't stand out when surrounded by such a garbage cast of characters. She's shy and actually entertaining, but they could have done much more with her.


I understand that Grand Blue's manga probably does the humor better than its anime, since most of the time, the source material is the superior of the two, but what about these horrible characters? What, are the manga's readers too busy laughing their asses off to realize that the characters are all terrible? Not likely.


I don't find Nichijou to be funny, but at least its characters are fine. Grand Blue isn't funny and its characters are bad.


Grand Blue is also filled with fan service. I'm not against fan service, as long as the show has other redeeming qualities, but Grand Blue sucks.


The art and animation are both solid, but characters having ugly facial expressions for the sole purpose of comedy, which I have mentioned multiple times isn't funny at all, just doesn't sit right with me. The anime's nudity is censored with black circles. Kind of weird.


~ Overall, Grand Blue didn't live up to my expectations.

Well well....what a roller coaster ride this anime was!! It was one of the funniest anime i have watched in a while. Here is a short review:

The story, the art, and mostly all other components are somewhat average. The anime itself isnt anything great if you want to be critical about it but damn is it funny.
